thread.title: Tens of thousands told to boil water after tests in Pittsburgh

title: Tens of thousands told to boil water after tests in Pittsburgh

organizations.name: the pittsburgh water and sewer authority

text:
Email 
PITTSBURGH -- The Pittsburgh Water and Sewer Authority is telling about 100,000 customers to boil their water before drinking it after low levels of chlorine were found in tests conducted by the state Department of Environmental Protection. 
The DEP has been testing the city’s water as part of an ongoing investigation into its water treatment system. 
The issue has prompted Pittsburgh Public Schools to close 22 schools and two early childhood centers on Wednesday. 
District officials said the closure will allow them time to properly cover water fountains, prepare food services and provide bottled water so schools are ready to open on Thursday if the advisory is still in effect, CBS Pittsburgh station KDKA-TV reports . 
Officials say low levels of chlorine could enable giardia to grow in the water. The parasite causes severe diarrhea. 
The advisory wasn’t expected to last more than three days. The city is setting up water buffaloes and other distribution points where residents can get bottled water. 
The water’s being tested every four hours until the DEP says it’s safe.   This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. The Associated Press contributed to this report.
